docs.lead_paragraph: Dangerous germs are everywhere. Or at least that is the message purveyed by Madison Avenue in advertisements for microbe-killing household products. But using antibacterial soaps at home does not add any more protection for healthy people against infections, researchers reported yesterday. In their study, published in The Annals of Internal Medicine, 238 households in Manhattan with at least one preschool child were given a year's worth of cleaning supplies and then were closely monitored for infections.

headline.main: Got Germs? Regular Soap Will Do

docs.abstract: Dr Elaine L Larson, Columbia University School of Nursing researcher, leads study that suggests that using antibacterial soaps at home does not lend additional protection against infections; study, published in Annals of Internal Medicine, finds no difference in number of bacterial infections in homes using antibacterial soap compared with homes using regular soaps; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Dangerous germs are everywhere. Or at least that is the message purveyed by Madison Avenue in advertisements for microbe-killing household products.    But using antibacterial soaps at home does not add any more protection for healthy people against...

docs.lead_paragraph: Get used to it. Pertussis, better known as whooping cough, is here to stay. So are pertussis-related deaths among vulnerable infants, unless steps are taken to stem the increasing number of cases of the highly contagious disease.

headline.main: Even With Vaccination, the 'Whoop' Is Back

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses resurgence of whooping cough in America; Brian Pascual, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention public health specialist, holds that pertussis, or whooping cough, is only vaccine-preventable disease on rise in United States; concerns about vaccination side effects in 1980's caused many parents to have children skip shots and opened door for return of illness, which caused deaths of 15 children in 2003; safer vaccine was developed in 1996 and immunization rates are increasing; whooping cough described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Get used to it. Pertussis, better known as whooping cough, is here to stay.    So are pertussis-related deaths among vulnerable infants, unless steps are taken to stem the increasing number of cases of the highly contagious disease.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Pat didn't know who I was felt as though we'd both been kidnapped. Her early onset Alzheimer's had been diagnosed four years earlier, but I never expected our connection to fracture so soon. After all, I had just quit the job I'd had for 10 years to better manage our living with the disease. We moved from Washington, D.C., to Florida, where Pat loved the warmth, the water, the bright flowers and the pelicans. After supper one night, we went to the ocean. Heading home, Pat was distressed and frightened. She asked who I was, what I was doing to her, where I was taking her. She tried to open the car door to escape.

headline.main: A Stranger In a House Of Memories

docs.abstract: Emerson D Moran article details his life with his 64-year-old wife Pat, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease; daily routine and insight into coping with person losing memory along with physical vitality discussed (M)
docs.snippet: The first time Pat didn't know who I was felt as though we'd both been kidnapped.    Her early onset Alzheimer's had been diagnosed four years earlier, but I never expected our connection to fracture so soon. After all, I had just quit the job I'd...

docs.lead_paragraph: Hype and prevarication may be the rule when it comes to spam. But truthfulness prevails in e-mail messages between people who know each other, a new study has found. Students who tracked their lies for a week reported telling lies in 15 percent of e-mail messages, compared with more than a third of phone calls, 25 percent of face-to-face conversations and about 20 percent of instant messaging chats.
docs.abstract: Cornell University Professor Jeffrey T Hancock presents study at Computer-Human Interaction conference in Vienna that shows people are less likely to lie in email than in face-to-face communications; holds that lies are generally spontaneous and people are more thoughtful about their written words; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Hype and prevarication may be the rule when it comes to spam. But truthfulness prevails in e-mail messages between people who know each other, a new study has found.    Students who tracked their lies for a week reported telling lies in 15 percent of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding folic acid to breads and grains sold in the United States has cut by a third the number of fetuses at risk for birth defects caused by folic acid deficiency, a new study has concluded. Low folate levels early in pregnancy can cause birth defects called neural tube defects, including spina bifida.

headline.main: For Babies, Going With the Grain

docs.abstract: Dr Mark I Evans of St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (NYC) leads study that shows that fortifying breads and grains with folic acid has cut number of fetuses at risk for birth defects caused by folic acid deficiency by one-third; study, on government-mandated folic acid supplements, is published in journal Obstetrics and Gynecology (S)
docs.snippet: Adding folic acid to breads and grains sold in the United States has cut by a third the number of fetuses at risk for birth defects caused by folic acid deficiency, a new study has concluded.    Low folate levels early in pregnancy can cause birth...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Gregory Davis hunched over an autopsy table last Thursday morning and cut into the lifeless body of a 52-year-old man. Days earlier, the man, who had no real health problems other than a smoking habit, had been found dead in his apartment, the victim of a heart attack, a coroner determined.

headline.main: Deaths Go Unexamined and the Living Pay the Price

docs.abstract: Autopsies, which were once performed in more than half of all hospital deaths and in vast majority of deaths outside hospital setting, have dropped sharply in number; decline is seen by some experts as diminishing overall quality of care since doctors do not find out about inaccurate diagnoses; recent studies on autopsies show that missed or incorrect diagnoses account for 25 percent of deaths; Dr Alain Combes, who led study on ICU patient death in Paris, France, holds that ICU patient autopsies are extremely valuable since there are more unexplained deaths and generally patients are sicker; study, which is published in Archives of Internal Medicine, finds more than 25 percent of diagnoses are questionable; financial woes and concern over malpractice cases have contributed to decline in autopsies; experts agree that even random autopsies would be beneficial; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Dr. Gregory Davis hunched over an autopsy table last Thursday morning and cut into the lifeless body of a 52-year-old man.     Days earlier, the man, who had no real health problems other than a smoking habit, had been found dead in his apartment,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Advances in reproductive technology seem always to take one step forward and two steps back. It happened again last month, when in the same week that scientists in South Korea were announcing that they had successfully cloned a human embryo, politicians in Italy were voting to throw that country's scientific efforts back into the dark ages.

headline.main: On High-Tech Reproduction, Italy Will Practice Abstinence

docs.abstract: Italian Parliament has passed legislation banning almost all forms of assisted reproduction; milestones in Italian reproductive science discussed; Rosana Della Cortes, then 63 years old, became oldest mother in 1994 when Roman gynecologist Dr Severino Antinori performed in vitro fertilization using donated egg and artificial hormones; new law prohibits women past childbearing age, single women and lesbians from obtaining in fertility treatments; forbids even basic procedures like artificial insemination with donated sperm; photos; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Advances in reproductive technology seem always to take one step forward and two steps back.    It happened again last month, when in the same week that scientists in South Korea were announcing that they had successfully cloned a human embryo,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Don Quixote said that hunger was the best sauce in the world. A new study suggests that he was right -- and any number of struggling dieters may agree. The study, published last week in BioMed Central Neuroscience, found that sensitivity to sweet and salty tastes was greater after 16 hours without food than an hour after a meal. Dr. Yuriy Zverev of the University of Malawi, the lead researcher, said a variety of factors -- including smoking, oral hygiene and food eaten earlier -- could affect taste sensitivity.

headline.main: Add a Dollop of Hunger for Taste

docs.abstract: Dr Yuiy Zverev, University of Malawi researcher, leads study showing that degree of hunger affects person's ability to discern specific tastes; study, published in BioMed Central Neuroscience, finds that person with full stomach pays less attention to taste; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Don Quixote said that hunger was the best sauce in the world. A new study suggests that he was right -- and any number of struggling dieters may agree.    The study, published last week in BioMed Central Neuroscience, found that sensitivity to sweet...
